From some experiments on the adhesion
of glue instituted by Mr.. Bevan. and an ac-
count Of which he has inserted IN the last
number of the Philosophical Magazine, It
appears that force Of ! $50 lbs applied at
right angles to the surface in contact. was
required to separate two cs slinders OF dry
asl-wood OF u inches in diameter, and a
bout inches long, after they had been
glued together q hours. The pressure


was applied gradually, and was sustained


two or three hours before the separation took


place. The force Of rs los. would, there


fore, bcrequired to separate one square insh.
The force required to separate dry Scotch
fir-wood 46a lbs: 60 the square inch; SO that
if two pieces Of this wood had been well
glued together, the wood would have yielded
in its substance before the glue The CO.
hesion of solid glue WAS 1000 lbs. TO the


square inch: from this it may be inferred


that the application of this substance as a


cement is susceptible OF Improvement.


Monthly Magazine.
CURIOUS EXPERIMENTS

In the news paper of the Bavarian Agri-
cultural Society, the nette is said to have
the following properties: eaten in salad, 1t
relieves consumption; it fattens horned cat
tie, whether eaten green or dried; it not on
ly fattens calves, but improves their flesh;
Il is an antidote to most maladies; sheep
which eat it bring forth healthy, vigorous
lambs; it promotes the laying of eggs IN
hens; it improves the fat of the pigs; the
seeds, mixed with oats, are excellent for
horses; it grows all the year round, even in
the coldest weather, and the hbres OF the
stem make an excellent hemp. The Bava-
rian Journal might have added, that few
plants force better OF more rapidly, and that
the tender shoots so produced make del
icatc and high Aavoured pot-herb, resem-
bling the points of the shoots of the pump
kin.


The nettle is much valued in Holland
where its young shoots are used as pot
herbs; its rect teg dyeing yellow; where th'

EASES OF HORSES.


Previous to setting out on long journey,
every precaution should be employed 70
bring horse into as perfect stase oi heai.n
a. possible If he has been scme eilhe A
grass, he should be taken up, ana kept III
Stable. week at least, previous 10 COM
rnsocing your journey. Il Is. likewise, prop
er TO examine his feet, and see that tncy are
in good order, and properly htted with
.hoes-The saddle or harness should pc IN
spected, Before a hcrse is taken out lot
long Journey, he should, tor fortnight pre-
yious. be rode out daily Tor exercise; not
merely walked about for twenty minutes Or
half an hour, but kept out tor an hour or
two. during which time he should have some
srotting, as well as walking exercise. 1t is
advisable 10 have the horse shoed tour or
FIVE DAYS before he sets off on the journey;
because they do not fit him, or It nail be
driven too close, the can be corrected with
ont much Inconvenience. Should he be at all
subject to grease, or swelling of the legs, a
dose of physic is to be recommended, taking
care TO preserve the heels clean, and to keep
up brisk circulation in the legs by hand
rubbing. Should the feet of the horse be
tender, it is necessary to inquire into the
cause of that tenderness: if it arise from
corps, let the directions be followed, which
will be given under that head. Ii II pro-
ceed from thin or fat soles, great care is
required in adapting the shoes to the feet,
and mailing them securely; as such teet are
generally thin and brittle, and the loss OF
shoe might occasion severe lameness. Inc
Domestic Encyclopedias recommends TO ap-
ply tar to thin and Eat soles, and TO let the
horse stand upon q flat surface, without
shoes, by which means they are rendered
Err1. and when he Ill-
den. let the concave shoe be made use Of
If the frog. are tender from thrushes let
them be made perfectly clean, and then
dressed at first with solution OF white or
blue yitriol, or of sugar of lead, afterwards
with tar IF the feet are hot, dry and In"
famed, lot them be softened and cooled by
poultice. If the thrushes are oceasioned by
contraction of the heels, which is frequent
Iy the case, it will be necessary to rasp
she quarters moderately, and should they
appear to be too strong, wanting proper
degree of elasticity, keep the noofs constant
ly moist Horses that travel through the
winter are very liable TO have their heels
inflamed and cracked, as it is termed, unless
great attention is paid to them in the stable.
in case, where the heels are already thus
affected, they should be washed in moderate
ly warm water or soap suds, as soon as
the horse gets in, and afterwards carefully
wiped dry with cloth; if much infiamed, a
noultice. and afterwards the following astrin-
gent lotions are to be applied


Alum powdered OF,


v,triolic acid (sulphuric scid) DR..


Water pint.
And if there be any ulcers or cracks use 1ie
following astringent ointment


Venice turpensine o.


Hou,. lard a OF.


Alum, finely powdered o.


And let the following Alternative powder b'
given occasionally.


Powdered rosin and nitro, OF each OF


Mix, and divide into eight doses.


When horses wind appears to be i'm
perfect, he should not be allowed to fill him
self with hav or water, and must be pre-
vented from eating his litter, which horse
of this description are generally inclined t
do, particularly when stinted IN hay.


AS soon as horse comes into the stable
let his feet be well cleaned, and all dirt o
gravel carefully removed. tits very CON
mon practice with ostlers, even IN winter, t
tie the horse up in the yard, that he ma,
undergo the ceremony Of having his heel
washed with cold water. This should ne
yer be permitted during the winter as man
bad consequences may arise from It. Durn
not HedlnST WUcl tUC ioauo dIN Wy uh
dusty, allow the horse to drink small qnM
tisy now and then, while on the road; thi
not only refreshes him considerably, but ha
the useful effect Of cooling and moistenin
his hoofs, as he will generally be made
stand in the water while drinking, nor
there the least danger to be apprehende
from it, unless he is rode very hard immed
ately before or after. In winter shoul
never be taken into the water, if it can b
avoided conveniently. A soft blanket vi
der the saddle in cool weather has the ter
dency to preserve the horses back, but it
too heating in warm.


Should the back Of your horse get sol
Nv saddle gals. or other inhamed tumour
wash the part affected with crude sal an
moniac, dissolved in vinegar or water;
with any ardent spirits alone, which must
done very frequently to prevent matte
from forming, in which case the sore will
more troublesome and difficult to heal. Yt
must also take especial care TO prevent al
friction or bearing of the pad of the sadd
upon the tumour, which may be effectual
done bv cutting small slit or hole IN Il
part of the pad, which bears immediate
upon the tumour, and pull out SO much


the .tuf5ng as will prevent any bearing;
.b;. nav he done without any essential inj

ris, Jr. Of Vernon, Vt. publishes the follow
ing in the Brattleboro' paper-"l have an
apple tree that blossomed in May, June, Ju.

EytraorGinnTy instance Or natural Gtce-
ron and frrocny ofa Cat--Ihe following
facts are well authenticated / a family III
the Lower Town Of Quebec, had cat with
kittens about two months old. one day the
mistress Of the house had occasion 70 open
cupboard where proSislu.'s were kept, and
on shutting IT, a kitten got squeezed by the
door. and uttered loud and plercln5 CIV
The mistress Of the house, after seeing that
it was discngaged, apparently not much
hurt turned TO 80 to another part ot tine
room. Presently the mother Of the kitten
came in. went up II il, and thrn flew turi
ously AZ the mistress Of the house, first Bit
Ing and scratching her legs, Thighs and arms,
and proceeding to her nec&, upon which She
fxed. the woman used her hands to pre-
serve her ewes, lowering ler head to save
her throat. her cries alarmed her husband,
who came into the room to her assistance c,
the cat then let go her hold, received a KICK,
passed under the stove 70 the other side OF It
where She was followed by the man, she
then repassed making again at the woman;
but being pursued she went out OF the door,
which was immediately closed. She then
began 20 fly up against the door uttering hid
eous cries; the family was SO much alarmed
that assistance was had, and finally the car
was killed on entering the door, partially
opened for the purpose. Ihe woman was


much hurt. but her wounds are nearly heal


ed. The cat had frequently shown symp-


toms of boldness and teroclty when irritatcd,
but never before i'll a way to excite alarm


in the family.

Interesting to Dyers and H6ad Gro,rerS.-A


new method of preparing Doad. for dying in blue,
has been read BY Messrs Robiquct and Colin,
before the Royal Academy OF Sciences at Paiis,


the title of which is "Researches on the colorlng


principle in woad" BY means OF new process.


these chemists have succeeded in obtaining very


expedltiolisy and economically that precious
article, which now sells from fourteen to fifteen
francs an ounce for the purest cakes, which will
very likely soon be obtained by the pound tor
the present price now paid for an ounce. They
designate under the name Of alzarine, the tncto-
rial matter in woad, which they believe 10 have


obtained in its greatest purity by the following


process. Their researches had induced them to


propose the alcoolck fermentation, which olsen
,, cages all heterogeneous substances, which might
impair its beauty, at the same time that It does
no injury to its fine coloring substance But
they now propose the following method, as be-
;np much more expeditions. Grind well the
woad and add two or three parts OF clear water,
! subject the whole to a very strong pressure, re
E neat the same operation three successive times
: bruisc well the residue and suffer it to be thu
v exposed to liquid bath with hive or SIX part
t of water added to it, in which sutheient quan
: tty of alum has been previously dissolved' after
: ward strain well that liquid and precipltate It D.
i an addition of subcarbonate OF SODA Inc pre-


cipitate thus produced must be very caretuil
!, washed in clear water. The naceration IN aiur
: wateris then continued till it become OF a proT
C erly thick consistencc. BY the ABOVE process

JYcmen. take care ofyour needies.-Mr.
Benjamin Douglass. of Stephentown, n. y.
had an OK taken sick about the middle OF
July last; various were the opinions about
the cause; any, however, but the true one
was assigned, until the OK was killed on
Thursday last. when on examination large
daraing needle was found in his heart-the
heart had become entirely liberated, was OF
the size of bushel basket, and weighed hi
ty-four pounds and nine ounces. containing
about four pounds of liberated matter.--
The needle was probably taken by the OK
in apple parings.

A writer in Bavarian journal recon-
mends sowing borage, and when it is full
grown ploughing it down as manure, the
good effects of which he has proved by long
experience. What renders it preferable to
most other plants for this purpose. is the
great quantity of soda and other salts which
it contains; it may be sown in April, and
ploughed down in August, in time to be toi-
lowed by wheat.


Philadelphia.N ational Gaz

Temperature, Greatest deg. Greatest deg of


Of cold, s. heat, S8.

full articles.headline: CURIOUS EXPERIMENTS
full articles.article:
From some experiments on the adhesion
of glue instituted by Mr.. Bevan. and an ac-
count Of which he has inserted IN the last
number of the Philosophical Magazine, It
appears that force Of ! $50 lbs applied at
right angles to the surface in contact. was
required to separate two cs slinders OF dry
asl-wood OF u inches in diameter, and a
bout inches long, after they had been
glued together q hours. The pressure


was applied gradually, and was sustained


two or three hours before the separation took


place. The force Of rs los. would, there


fore, bcrequired to separate one square insh.
The force required to separate dry Scotch
fir-wood 46a lbs: 60 the square inch; SO that
if two pieces Of this wood had been well
glued together, the wood would have yielded
in its substance before the glue The CO.
hesion of solid glue WAS 1000 lbs. TO the


square inch: from this it may be inferred


that the application of this substance as a


cement is susceptible OF Improvement.


Monthly Magazine.

full articles.headline: THE NETTLE.
full articles.article:
In the news paper of the Bavarian Agri-
cultural Society, the nette is said to have
the following properties: eaten in salad, 1t
relieves consumption; it fattens horned cat
tie, whether eaten green or dried; it not on
ly fattens calves, but improves their flesh;
Il is an antidote to most maladies; sheep
which eat it bring forth healthy, vigorous
lambs; it promotes the laying of eggs IN
hens; it improves the fat of the pigs; the
seeds, mixed with oats, are excellent for
horses; it grows all the year round, even in
the coldest weather, and the hbres OF the
stem make an excellent hemp. The Bava-
rian Journal might have added, that few
plants force better OF more rapidly, and that
the tender shoots so produced make del
icatc and high Aavoured pot-herb, resem-
bling the points of the shoots of the pump
kin.


The nettle is much valued in Holland
where its young shoots are used as pot
herbs; its rect teg dyeing yellow; where th'

HENRY REALD,
full articles.article:
Has opened his ACADEMY, at his residence, IN
French street, two doors below Third street,
where will be taught the different branches Of
practical Mathematics the method of taking and
working Lunar Observations; with the uses and
adjustment of all the instruments used in the
branches taught.


Should sufficient encouragement be given to
afford tia small photographic and Printing Press
will be attached to the Institution, by which the
pupils may be exercised i'll composition; Perspec'
tive and other drawings; things, essential to the
practical Scholar


Pupils from distance will be accommodated
with Boarding at Two Dollars per week.

full articles.headline: MANUFACTURING or CALICO.
full articles.article:
Till within very short time il is well
known that this article has demanded high
price among retailers who have kept none
but such as was imported from Europe.
Manufacturers have at length introduced
the business of making Calcoes OF their own,
and there are now many valuable establish
ments in the country which produce this
Kind of cloth Of the first quality. Within
two years the article has been reduced in
price 80 per cent, which is doubtless to be
attributed to the success of our manuflc
turcs.

full articles.headline:
TIE FARMER.

From the New-England Farmer.
ON THE MANAGEMENT AND Oio-


EASFS OF HORSES,
full articles.article:
ON THE MAN AtIEMf EN- nAN0 -


EASES OF HORSES.


Previous to setting out on long journey,
every precaution should be employed 70
bring horse into as perfect stase oi heai.n
a. possible If he has been scme eilhe A
grass, he should be taken up, ana kept III
Stable. week at least, previous 10 COM
rnsocing your journey. Il Is. likewise, prop
er TO examine his feet, and see that tncy are
in good order, and properly htted with
.hoes-The saddle or harness should pc IN
spected, Before a hcrse is taken out lot
long Journey, he should, tor fortnight pre-
yious. be rode out daily Tor exercise; not
merely walked about for twenty minutes Or
half an hour, but kept out tor an hour or
two. during which time he should have some
srotting, as well as walking exercise. 1t is
advisable 10 have the horse shoed tour or
FIVE DAYS before he sets off on the journey;
because they do not fit him, or It nail be
driven too close, the can be corrected with
ont much Inconvenience. Should he be at all
subject to grease, or swelling of the legs, a
dose of physic is to be recommended, taking
care TO preserve the heels clean, and to keep
up brisk circulation in the legs by hand
rubbing. Should the feet of the horse be
tender, it is necessary to inquire into the
cause of that tenderness: if it arise from
corps, let the directions be followed, which
will be given under that head. Ii II pro-
ceed from thin or fat soles, great care is
required in adapting the shoes to the feet,
and mailing them securely; as such teet are
generally thin and brittle, and the loss OF
shoe might occasion severe lameness. Inc
Domestic Encyclopedias recommends TO ap-
ply tar to thin and Eat soles, and TO let the
horse stand upon q flat surface, without
shoes, by which means they are rendered
Err1. and when he Ill-
den. let the concave shoe be made use Of
If the frog. are tender from thrushes let
them be made perfectly clean, and then
dressed at first with solution OF white or
blue yitriol, or of sugar of lead, afterwards
with tar IF the feet are hot, dry and In"
famed, lot them be softened and cooled by
poultice. If the thrushes are oceasioned by
contraction of the heels, which is frequent
Iy the case, it will be necessary to rasp
she quarters moderately, and should they
appear to be too strong, wanting proper
degree of elasticity, keep the noofs constant
ly moist Horses that travel through the
winter are very liable TO have their heels
inflamed and cracked, as it is termed, unless
great attention is paid to them in the stable.
in case, where the heels are already thus
affected, they should be washed in moderate
ly warm water or soap suds, as soon as
the horse gets in, and afterwards carefully
wiped dry with cloth; if much infiamed, a
noultice. and afterwards the following astrin-
gent lotions are to be applied


Alum powdered OF,


v,triolic acid (sulphuric scid) DR..


Water pint.
And if there be any ulcers or cracks use 1ie
following astringent ointment


Venice turpensine o.


Hou,. lard a OF.


Alum, finely powdered o.


And let the following Alternative powder b'
given occasionally.


Powdered rosin and nitro, OF each OF


Mix, and divide into eight doses.


When horses wind appears to be i'm
perfect, he should not be allowed to fill him
self with hav or water, and must be pre-
vented from eating his litter, which horse
of this description are generally inclined t
do, particularly when stinted IN hay.


AS soon as horse comes into the stable
let his feet be well cleaned, and all dirt o
gravel carefully removed. tits very CON
mon practice with ostlers, even IN winter, t
tie the horse up in the yard, that he ma,
undergo the ceremony Of having his heel
washed with cold water. This should ne
yer be permitted during the winter as man
bad consequences may arise from It. Durn
not HedlnST WUcl tUC ioauo dIN Wy uh
dusty, allow the horse to drink small qnM
tisy now and then, while on the road; thi
not only refreshes him considerably, but ha
the useful effect Of cooling and moistenin
his hoofs, as he will generally be made
stand in the water while drinking, nor
there the least danger to be apprehende
from it, unless he is rode very hard immed
ately before or after. In winter shoul
never be taken into the water, if it can b
avoided conveniently. A soft blanket vi
der the saddle in cool weather has the ter
dency to preserve the horses back, but it
too heating in warm.


Should the back Of your horse get sol
Nv saddle gals. or other inhamed tumour
wash the part affected with crude sal an
moniac, dissolved in vinegar or water;
with any ardent spirits alone, which must
done very frequently to prevent matte
from forming, in which case the sore will
more troublesome and difficult to heal. Yt
must also take especial care TO prevent al
friction or bearing of the pad of the sadd
upon the tumour, which may be effectual
done bv cutting small slit or hole IN Il
part of the pad, which bears immediate
upon the tumour, and pull out SO much


the .tuf5ng as will prevent any bearing;
.b;. nav he done without any essential inj

full articles.headline: Philadelphia National Gaz.
full articles.article:
Strange .fthle 7tee-M. Sylvanus Har-
ris, Jr. Of Vernon, Vt. publishes the follow
ing in the Brattleboro' paper-"l have an
apple tree that blossomed in May, June, Ju.
", August, September and October last, and
had six growths of apples. as many OF my
ncighbors will attest TO- The first growth
came to maturity like my other apples; the
other growths had no seeds in them, but
grew as fast as other apples. s."-Hamh. GGz.

iorse-deaiers give. siic seeds to horses 20
make them brisk, and give them fine skim
and where considerable portions Of fields are
planted with it, aud mown five or six times
year, as green food. The acorn, irr forest
districts, in Saxony, is successfully used to
fatten sheep during the winter.

EytraorGinnTy instance Or natural Gtce-
ron and frrocny ofa Cat--Ihe following
facts are well authenticated / a family III
the Lower Town Of Quebec, had cat with
kittens about two months old. one day the
mistress Of the house had occasion 70 open
cupboard where proSislu.'s were kept, and
on shutting IT, a kitten got squeezed by the
door. and uttered loud and plercln5 CIV
The mistress Of the house, after seeing that
it was discngaged, apparently not much
hurt turned TO 80 to another part ot tine
room. Presently the mother Of the kitten
came in. went up II il, and thrn flew turi
ously AZ the mistress Of the house, first Bit
Ing and scratching her legs, Thighs and arms,
and proceeding to her nec&, upon which She
fxed. the woman used her hands to pre-
serve her ewes, lowering ler head to save
her throat. her cries alarmed her husband,
who came into the room to her assistance c,
the cat then let go her hold, received a KICK,
passed under the stove 70 the other side OF It
where She was followed by the man, she
then repassed making again at the woman;
but being pursued she went out OF the door,
which was immediately closed. She then
began 20 fly up against the door uttering hid
eous cries; the family was SO much alarmed
that assistance was had, and finally the car
was killed on entering the door, partially
opened for the purpose. Ihe woman was


much hurt. but her wounds are nearly heal


ed. The cat had frequently shown symp-


toms of boldness and teroclty when irritatcd,
but never before i'll a way to excite alarm


in the family.

Interesting to Dyers and H6ad Gro,rerS.-A


new method of preparing Doad. for dying in blue,
has been read BY Messrs Robiquct and Colin,
before the Royal Academy OF Sciences at Paiis,


the title of which is "Researches on the colorlng


principle in woad" BY means OF new process.


these chemists have succeeded in obtaining very


expedltiolisy and economically that precious
article, which now sells from fourteen to fifteen
francs an ounce for the purest cakes, which will
very likely soon be obtained by the pound tor
the present price now paid for an ounce. They
designate under the name Of alzarine, the tncto-
rial matter in woad, which they believe 10 have


obtained in its greatest purity by the following


process. Their researches had induced them to


propose the alcoolck fermentation, which olsen
,, cages all heterogeneous substances, which might
impair its beauty, at the same time that It does
no injury to its fine coloring substance But
they now propose the following method, as be-
;np much more expeditions. Grind well the
woad and add two or three parts OF clear water,
! subject the whole to a very strong pressure, re
E neat the same operation three successive times
: bruisc well the residue and suffer it to be thu
v exposed to liquid bath with hive or SIX part
t of water added to it, in which sutheient quan
: tty of alum has been previously dissolved' after
: ward strain well that liquid and precipltate It D.

JYcmen. take care ofyour needies.-Mr.
Benjamin Douglass. of Stephentown, n. y.
had an OK taken sick about the middle OF
July last; various were the opinions about
the cause; any, however, but the true one
was assigned, until the OK was killed on
Thursday last. when on examination large
daraing needle was found in his heart-the
heart had become entirely liberated, was OF
the size of bushel basket, and weighed hi
ty-four pounds and nine ounces. containing
about four pounds of liberated matter.--
The needle was probably taken by the OK
in apple parings.

A writer in Bavarian journal recon-
mends sowing borage, and when it is full
grown ploughing it down as manure, the
good effects of which he has proved by long
experience. What renders it preferable to
most other plants for this purpose. is the
great quantity of soda and other salts which
it contains; it may be sown in April, and
ploughed down in August, in time to be toi-
lowed by wheat.
